adept.common
Class DocumentEvent

java.lang.Object
  adept.common.Item
      adept.common.HltContent
          adept.common.DocumentEvent
All Implemented Interfaces:
HasAttributes
public final class DocumentEvent
extends HltContent
implements HasAttributes

Represents an event at the level of participating document-level entities, rather than strings of text.

What follows is a description of the structure of all event-related classes in the ADEPT API from two perspective: first, in terms of the API's internal logic and the distinctions made in its data structures, and, second, in terms of how DEFT event algorithm output ought to be mapped to these data structures.

API Data Structure Rationale

There are two main axes of variation central to the API. The first is the representation of event participants, whether as spans of text (textual events) or as entities/resolved values (document-level events). The second is that we may wish to express the mere occurrence of some event, the arguments involved in an event, or both together.

Representing Textual Events

  • Representing the occurrence of textual events, (e.g. a particular span of text in sentence three indicates that a Life.Marry event occurred) is handled by EventText. The API is agnostic as to the number and sizes of the spans of text justifying the event's occurrence. It could range from single trigger words to multiple non-continguous sentences.
  • Representing the arguments of textual events (e.g. a particular span of text is the Victim of a Conflict.Attack event) is handled by EventMentionArgument. The text of the argument can be a EntityMention, a TimePhrase, or any other kind of Chunk.
  • Grouping together the arguments of the same textual expression of an event is handled by EventMention. This may optionally also link the arguments to an EventText.

Intermediate levels

If you wish to represent a grouping of textual events without regard for their arguments, use an EventTextSet. These may optionally be converted to DocumentEvents (see below) without arguments, but beware that by doing so you are abusing the semantics of the classes somewhat (since you do not wish to assert that the DocumentEvents are in fact argumentless) and may get invalid results from some downstream algorithms.

Representing Entity-level Events

  • DocumentEventArgument.Filler represents something which fills an argument role of a document-level event. Currently this is either an Entity or a TemporalValue
    • .
  • To represent the participation of an DocumentEventArgument.Filler in an event, use DocumentEventArgument. An DocumentEventArgument may have optionally have DocumentEventArgument.Provenances linking it to supporting EventMentionArgument(s).
  • To represent an event at the document-level, independent of any single textual realization, use DocumentEvent, which gathers together DocumentEventArguments. An Event may optionally have DocumentEvent.Provenances linking it to supporting EventMentions and EventTexts. DocumentEvent is an event-level parallel to an entity. Therefore, no DocumentEvents in the same document should be in an identity-coreference relationship with each other. Document-level events are appropriate for eventual storage in a knowledge-base.

There is another older event class, Event, which is roughly equivalent to EventMention. However, use of the newer classes described here is strongly encouraged because they provide several advantages, most importantly the possibility of reification, allowing event coreference and event-event relations to be expressed. An Event may be converted to an approximating EventMention using the Event.asEventMention() method.

Algorithms differ greatly in exactly what objects they score, so most event classes have an optional score field. Interpretation of this field is algorithm-specific. Most of the classes also implement HasAttributes, allowing algorithms to mark e.g. realis at varying levels. Interpretation of attributes is algorithm-specific.

All event-related classes are locally immutable, which is to say that once created, you cannot alter their event-specific information. However, the fields associated with their HltContent super-class are mutable, as are some of their contained types such as Chunk.

Most of these classes are constructed using the fluent builder pattern. Please see com.bbn.EventTest for many examples.

Mapping from DEFT Event Algorithms to this API

  • ACE and ERE event mentions: The triggers should be EventTexts, the arguments should be EventMentionArguments, and the should be joined together in EventMentions. Modality, genericity, etc. should be represented by scored attributes on EventMention.
  • ACE and ERE events should be represented by DocumentEvents.
  • NIST's 2014 Event Mention Detection Evaluation event nuggets should be EventTexts with realis indicated using scored attributes.
  • TAC KBP 2014 Event Arguments should be represented as DocumentEventArguments where the entity corresponds to the canonical argument string and justifications and basefillers are indicated by DocumentEventArgument.Provenances wrapping EventMentionArguments.

Concerning Event Types

The types of events may come from either a closed ontology or an open one (e.g. predicates drawn from natural language). Either is acceptable to the API. In the latter case, you can construct new types using Type.Type(String).

Concerning Reification of Arguments a System Cannot Coref

Many systems may be unable to coreference certain argument types (e.g. crimes). In such cases, it is recommend that the algorithm create singleton entities for these when creating DocumentEvents.
